attributes.title: Illinois Tool Works: Q2 Portfolio Review
summary: This article reviews my 24-stock retirement income portfolio and highlights a holding from the Industrials sector: Illinois Tool Works.
The purpose of the portfolio is to provide supplemental retirement income through a relatively safe, growing dividend stream.
The priority is relative dividend safety, with the potential for earnings and dividend growth. I rank the holdings based on eight metrics.
The 24-stock portfolio yield on 6/30/21 was 3.18%. The portfolio year-to-date gain has been 11.4%.

attributes.content:
Introduction

Illinois Tool Works (NYSE:ITW) produces specialized industrial products, has an A+ S&P credit rating and has raised the dividend 46 consecutive years. The 2020 10-K describes seven segments with 83 divisions in 52 countries; 43,000 employees; and 440 plants and facilities globally.

Q2 Snapshot

ITW set several Q1 records, including $2.11 EPS, $905 million operating income and 25.5% margin. SG&A is steadily 17% of sales.

ITW expects 10-12% full year organic growth, 25-26% operating margin, and $8.20-$8.60 GAAP EPS. If the mid-point of guidance is reached, EPS would be up 27% from 2020 and up 9% from pre-COVID 2019 EPS of $7.74.

ITW plans to repurchase approximately $1 billion of its shares in 2021.

Half of revenues are ex-US. Q1 revenue is shown below, in millions, per their Q1 Release, and some brand names:

  1. Automotive OEM, $783. Deltar and Shakeproof;
  2. Test & Measurement/Electronics, $552, Instron;
  3. Construction Products, $469, Paslode;
  4. Specialty Products, $457, Hi-Cone;
  5. Food Equipment, $451, Hobart;
  6. Polymers & Fluids, $435, Rain-X and Permatex; and
  7. Welding, $401, Miller.

Q1 GAAP EPS was $2.11; operating income $905 million; operating margin 25.5%; free cash flow $541 million, 81% of net income. A Q1 earnings call presentation shows organic revenue growth, highlighting the largest segment (Automotive):

A Distinctive Business Model

In 2012, ITW began a determined effort to fully leverage its business model's three elements, described on pp. 4-6 of the 2020 10-K:

  1. ITW's 80/20 Front-to-Back process, initially a 1980s efficiency tool, is a proprietary, holistic management process, focusing on best opportunities (the "80"), avoiding cost, complexity and distractions of weaker opportunities (the "20").
  2. Customer-back Innovation works from the customer back, to be the go-to problem solver for their "80" customers, solving problems particularly for the growing "80" markets. Customer insights drive ITW's innovation, including 18,500 granted and pending patents;
  3. ITW's Decentralized, Entrepreneurial Culture reflects a flexible business model that executes the company’s strategy and values to best serve customers. Execution of a focused, simple organizational structure delivers best-in-class services and solutions adapted to each end market.

Strengths

ITW is a serial innovator, evidenced by 1,900 new patent applications in 2020.

CEO Scott Santi, 59, said in the Q1 call, "We source where we produce.” ITW carries "surplus capacity (of) 15% to 20%…. we can produce today what our customers bought yesterday… (by having) ample extra capacity to flex."

CFO Michael Larsen, 52, gave 35-40% margin estimates, expecting "really strong performance ... as the recovery takes hold.”

Weaknesses

Larsen said their Automotive segment will have the most margin pressure "given the nature of the business and how contracts are structured...."

Food Equipment was hard hit by the pandemic. In the Q1 call, analyst Ann Duignan asked, "What about … restaurants (that) cannot hire…?”

Analyst Julian Mitchell asked if receivables caused "flattish" Q1 cash flow. Larsen said, "As sales grow, inventories and receivables grow. … receivable aging and our bad debt ... are (meaningfully) below pre-COVID levels."

Opportunities

ITW intends to "Win the Recovery" with its decentralized, entrepreneurial culture that executes "flexibility within the framework" for better performance.

In the Q1 call, Santi said one to three MTS type deals annually is reasonable, but Santi said, “We (will not) buy anything to consolidate.... we compete based on our ability to deliver superior value to the customers.”

Asked about large acquisitions, Santi said, "I don’t think size is a barrier .... We have never been more prepared ... a result of the last nine years of work on this.” (The primary question is) "does it fit an area of the market we think has long-term above market organic growth prospects….”

Threats

China poses ITW's greatest potential threat in the form of their government exerting control over their companies.

ITW's largest segment (Automotive OEM) has the threat of general uncertainty in the automobile market.

Asked about electric-powered vehicles, Santi said, "(Some of what) we do around the powertrain now … wouldn’t exist, but there’s a whole range of new… applications in the EV space."

F.A.S.T. Graph

The graph below shows ITW's strength following the Spring 2020 downturn. The company appears well-positioned to ramp up profits by maximizing the benefits of its decade-long focus on its business model, with a current emphasis on maximizing organic growth in all its divisions.

From F.A.S.T. Graphs

The Dividend

The current quarterly dividend is $1.14, annualized to $4.56. ITW's 5-year dividend growth rate is 15.69%.

If ITW meets the midpoint of 2021 GAAP EPS guidance of $8.40, the payout ratio for the current dividend would be 54.29%. The 5-year average payout ratio has been 53.58%.

At a July 7 closing price of $225.21, the current yield is 2.02%. The 5-year average high yield was 3.12%, with the highest yield of 3.8% in 2020.

Personal Investment Thesis

Illinois Tool Works is 3.3% of my 24-stock retirement income portfolio. I use eight factors to rate these companies:

  1. S&P Credit Rating. ITW's A+ rating scores 5 points on a scale ranging from 9 points for AAA to 1 point for BBB.
  2. Consecutive Years of Dividend Increases. I divide this number by 10, so ITW's 46 years equal a score of 4.6. The portfolio range is 0.9 to 6.5.
  3. Current Dividend Yield. ITW's $225.21 closing price on 7/7/21 translates to a 2.02% yield. I multiply by 100 for a score of 2.02. The portfolio yields range from 0.61% to 5.47%, so scores for this factor are 0.61 to 5.47.
  4. Payout Ratio. I use F.A.S.T. Graphs' earnings estimates. ITW's estimated adjusted EPS is $11.40. The $4.56 dividend is 40.00% of this estimate. A low payout ratio gives more flexibility for dividend growth. I subtract the payout ratio from 100%, which for ITW is 60.0%. I multiply this by 10, giving ITW a 6.0 payout ratio score. Scores for this factor range from 1.4 to 8.5.
  5. Five-year Dividend Growth Rate. I use Seeking Alpha's data. To maintain parity with other factors, I multiply the growth rate by 0.5. For example, ITW's 5-year dividend growth rate is 15.69%, or 15.69, which I multiply by 0.5, for a score of 7.845. Scores range from 0.8 to 10.9.
  6. The Quant Score from Seeking Alpha. This is "an objective, unemotional evaluation of each stock based on over 100 metrics, such as the company's financial statement, stock price performance, and analysts' estimates of the company's future revenue and earnings, relative to other companies in the stock's sector. The rating is from 1.0 to 5.0, with 1.0 being very bearish and 5.0 being very bullish." For example, ITW's quant score is 3.16.
  7. Dividend Safety Score. This is from Simply Safe Dividends, which rates the safety of a company's dividend on a score of 0 to 100, with 50 being average. For parity, I divide the dividend safety score by 10. For example, Illinois Tool Works' dividend safety score of 81 becomes 8.1.
  8. Long-term Debt to Total Capital. I use Seeking Alpha for this metric. Lower is better, (like the payout ratio), so I subtract ITW's 67.70 LT debt from 100%, to get 32.30%. I multiply by 10, giving ITW a score of 3.23

These eight factors give ITW a combined score of 39.96, which ranks ITW 11th among the 24 portfolio companies.

Q2 Portfolio Review

On 6/30/21, the portfolio's 24 equities had a 3.18% aggregate yield. The year-to-date gain has been 11.4%. The cash position is 2.7%.

The current portfolio distribution rate is 2.7%. This will approximate 3.9% in 2022, when Required Minimum Distribution begins. The 6/30/21 sector representation was: Health Care 19.1%; Information Technology 14,6%; Financials 14.0%; Utilities 12.9%; Consumer Staples 12.8%; Real Estate 11.9%; Industrials 8.2%; and Discretionary 3.8%.

Several positions were closed in Q2:

  • Canadian Utilities (OTCPK:CDUAF) closed in April at $27.16, held 13 months for a gain of 18%, ex-dividends. I love the company, but it might be difficult for my beneficiary to manage.
  • Prologis (PLD) closed in April at $108.56, held one month, for a gain of 15%. This great REIT has continued to go up, but I opted for a higher yield.
  • Verizon Communications (VZ) closed in April at $57.42, held 11 months, for a gain of 3.7%, ex-dividends. It will be increasingly capital intensive and difficult to regain an A- S&P credit rating.
  • AT&T (T) closed in April at $29.98, held (this time) 11 months, for a gain of 6.7%, ex-dividends. I lost confidence in management.
  • Federal Realty Investment Trust (FRT) closed in April at $104.98, held 15 months, for a gain of 45%, ex-dividends. This was the toughest decision.
  • Genuine Parts (GPC) closed in May at $132.13, held 21 months, for a gain of 62%, ex-dividends. I might re-enter at a lower valuation, especially if they were to buy Rock Auto.
  • Camden Property Trust (CPT) closed in May at $122.21, held 11 months, for a gain of 36%, ex-dividends. Great management. Maybe later.

In Q2, positions in four previously-held companies were added:

  • Automatic Data Processing (ADP), in April at $187.72, in spite of a $1 billion debt issuance brought a S&P credit downgrade from AA to AA-. It has powerful scale and unmatched proprietary data economic data.
  • Toronto-Dominion Bank (TD), in April at $65.68, shortly after highlighting TD in my Q1 Portfolio Review. I like the sale of TD Ameritrade to Schwab (SCHW), and TD's 13% stake in Schwab. TD has an AA- S&P credit rating.
  • Royal Bank of Canada (RY), in June at $102.29. It has quality, yield, and the favorable environment for big Canadian banks. RY and TD are the only two banks in North America with S&P credit ratings of AA-.
  • Realty Income (O), in June at $68.00. I like management and scale after acquiring Vereit. The stand-alone REIT sub-sector offers flexibility in a changing retail environment.

In Q2, Pinnacle West Capital Corporation (PNW) was added in June at $82.71. PNW is a utility holding company in the southwestern US. It has an A- S&P credit rating and has increased the dividend for 9 consecutive years.
